xyz.acygn.mokapot.wireformat

Class ObjectDescription

  • java.lang.Object
    • xyz.acygn.mokapot.util.DataByteBuffer
      • xyz.acygn.mokapot.wireformat.ObjectDescription
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DataInput, DataOutput, DescriptionOutput, ReadableDescription

    public class ObjectDescription
extends DataByteBuffer
implements ReadableDescription, DescriptionOutput
    An object's class, plus a flattened version of an object's fields. Any primitive or array-typed fields are converted into a sequence of bytes; any Copiable (or implicitly copiable) fields recursively have their class and fields included in the object description; any noncopiable fields are kept (at this stage) as references.

    The resulting data structure consists of two parts: a sequence of bytes containing the copiable portion of the object, and a sequence of references containing the noncopiable portion. The description can be converted to a marshalled form of the object via converting each reference to a ReferenceValue. Alternatively, it can be converted to a shallow copy of the original object via reversing the process used to construct it. (This differs from a serialisation of an object, which would be converted to a deep copy of the object upon being deserialised.)

    An object description is initially mutable and write-only, a "partial object description" that contains the object description so far. (In other words, it's more like a StringBuilder than a String.) Once writing to it is complete, calling close() makes it immutable and read-only, instead; it's now a fully complete description with a read cursor.

    An object description cannot expand once created; the caller should calculate the size of description needed before constructing it.

    Author:
    Alex Smith

    • Field Detail

      • IDENTIFIER_CHARSET

        public static final Charset IDENTIFIER_CHARSET
        The character set into which Java identifiers are encoded in order to store them in descriptions. Currently US-ASCII, but stored in a centralised location to make it easy to change for compatibility with non-English identifiers.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ObjectDescription

        public ObjectDescription(ObjectDescription.Size size)
        Creates a new object description. It will originally be empty, allowing data to be written to it.
        Parameters:
        size - The amount of data that will be written to the object description. This may be an overestimate.

    • Method Detail

      • resetForRead

        public void resetForRead()
        Makes this object description readable and read-only, and resets the read pointers. Used once writing to the object description is complete, or once reading the object description is complete (to allow it to be read again).
        Overrides:
        resetForRead in class DataByteBuffer

      • isRewound

        public boolean isRewound()
        Checks to see whether this description is rewound. That is, that the description has been placed into read-only mode, and the read cursor is currently at the start of its data (indicating that none of it was read since the previous reset) in both the copiable and noncopiable portions.

        This method differs from the method in the superclass, which only checks the noncopiable portion.

        Overrides:
        isRewound in class DataByteBuffer
        Returns:
        Whether this description is rewound.

      • writeNoncopiableObject

        public void writeNoncopiableObject(Object obj)
                            throws IOException
        Appends a reference to an object to the noncopiable part of the description.
        Specified by:
        writeNoncopiableObject in interface DescriptionOutput
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to append.
        Throws:
        IOException - If this description is full or read-only

      • readNoncopiableObject

        public <T> T readNoncopiableObject(Class<T> asClass)
                            throws IOException
        Reads an object from the noncopiable portion of this description. This operation can only be done reliably if the actual class of the object to read is already known. Note that if the wrong class is given, it may not be possible to detect this fact (although a ClassCastException may well be thrown in cases where it is detectable).
        Specified by:
        readNoncopiableObject in interface ReadableDescription
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class of the object to read.
        Parameters:
        asClass - T.class, given explicitly due to Java's type erasure rules.
        Returns:
        The object that was read.
        Throws:
        IOException - If the end of the description has been reached, or if the description is write-only

      • listAllNoncopiableObjects

        public List<?> listAllNoncopiableObjects()
        Reads the entire list of noncopiable objects. This is intended for use only by serialisation algorithms that serialise the entire object description in one go, and may well be hard to use in other contexts. (Note that it doesn't use the cursors, like most other methods do, so it can only be used when focusing on the entire description as a whole, and isn't useful to build up a description in a compositional way.)
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable list of noncopiable objects.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Produces a debug dump of the bytes that make up this description.
        Overrides:
        toString in class DataByteBuffer
        Returns:
        A string representation of the description.
